content.term: Hard and Soft Signs of Vascular Injury
content.definition: Clinical findings that indicate the presence and severity of vascular injury in extremity trauma. Hard signs have high positive predictive value (>95%) for significant vascular injury requiring intervention, while soft signs suggest possible injury warranting further evaluation.

hard_signs.definition: Findings with >95% PPV for vascular injury requiring operation
hard_signs.management_algorithm: Hard signs = OR (no imaging needed unless stable patient and OR not immediately available)

soft_signs.definition: Findings suggesting possible vascular injury, warranting further evaluation

signs.significance: May have had arterial bleeding now controlled
Possible intimal injury or partial transection

signs.sign: Proximity of wound to major vessel

signs.significance: May represent venous injury or contained arterial

soft_signs.management_algorithm: Soft signs = CTA or duplex ultrasound evaluation

ankle_brachial_index.role: Screening tool in patients with soft signs

imaging_approach.cta: Preferred for soft signs - rapid, high sensitivity/specificity
imaging_approach.duplex: Alternative when CT unavailable or contraindicated
imaging_approach.angiography: Therapeutic or when endovascular repair planned

learning_objectives: List the hard signs of vascular injury
Know appropriate management for each category
Understand role of ABI in trauma screening
clinical_pearls: ABI ≥0.9 effectively rules out significant injury
6 Ps: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesias, Paralysis, Poikilothermia
Proximity alone (soft sign) has only 10-20% injury rate - image, don't explore
